description: From Middle English erthequake, corresponding to earth +‎ quake. Displaced Old English eorþbeofung (literally “earth shaking”).

entries.meaning: A shaking of the ground, caused by volcanic activity or movement around geologic faults. [from 14th c.]
examples: Last year's earthquake crushed his house, his livelihood and very nearly his leg, he said, pointing to a plastered limb that refuses to heal.

entries.meaning: (planetary geology) Such a quake specifically occurring on the planet Earth, as opposed to other celestial bodies. [from 20th c.]
examples: Since the response of some man-made structures to the ground motion near the epicenter is highly dependent on frequency, a significant difference in potential damage to the structures is expected between earthquakes and moonquakes.

verbs.description: earthquake (third-person singular simple present earthquakes, present participle earthquaking, simple past and past participle earthquaked)

examples: Watch the Philippines very closely for the next little while. There is rumbling and earthquaking deep within Pinatubo and increased earthquaking within Mayon.
